Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Phylogenomics of palaeognathous birds and the genomic basis of flightlessness
Award.AbstractNarration:
Flightless birds, including species such as the ostrich and emu (which belong to a bird group called the ratites), present a remarkable series of traits related to their loss of flight. Such traits include shortening of the bones in the forelimbs, extreme increases or decreases in body size, loss of the breast bone to which the flight muscles attach, and many other modifications. Moreover, recent research suggests that this suite of traits may have evolved multiple times within the ratites. By studying the evolution of such traits and determining which regions of the genome likely underlie them, we can gain insight into how evolution occurs in parallel in the natural world. We can also gain a better understanding of the types of genes that change when morphological traits are lost in the way they have been in the ratites. Ultimately, a better understanding of links between genotype and phenotype can help us understand the genetic basis for variation in the human phenotype. We expect that some human malformations, including the loss of digits, bones in the hand or forelimbs, likely occur because of mutations in some of the same genes or regulatory regions that underlie flightlessness in the ratites. In fact, one way we will attempt to find the genetic underpinnings of flightlessness in the ratites is to examine the evolution of ratite genes that are known from previous studies to cause similar morphologies in laboratory mice. Thus this study will forge important links between mutations known in developmental studies in the lab and natural variations we find in distantly related vertebrates.

This project will use comparisons among the genomes of flightless birds, in combination with morphological studies and phylogenetic methods, to understand the genomic basis of traits contributing to flightlessness. Complete sequencing of the genomes of 8 ratite species will yield a robust genealogical tree of ratites and their relationships to the tinamous, a volant bird group closely related to, and likely embedded within, the ratites. This tree will in turn permit identification of conserved regulatory regions occurring near genes known to contribute to limb loss in better-studied models for development, such as chickens and mice. The timing of origin and loss of regulatory regions, such as conserved regions occurring outside of genes, will reveal important clues about the regulatory and genetic basis of trait evolution in flightless birds. Previous phylogenetic work in the strongly suggests that flight likely was lost independently in multiple lineages of ratites in parallel. This scenario will add statistical power to our inferences of the genomic underpinnings of morphological change, because it will allow us to identify genomic regions that have changed independently in flightless lineages. Thus, this project will also elucidate how convergent morphological changes occur at the genomic level. These themes will be used in a number of outreach activities, including an educational video, classroom teaching of undergraduates, and graduate student outreach in local K-12 schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How and why do birds lose their wings and their ability to fly? And what does this tell us about the many ways in which genes and their regulation contribute to morphological diversity in nature? These questions and others were studied as part of this NSF-funded project. Specifically we were interested in learning what genetic mechanisms underlay the dramatic loss of flight and associated skeletal morphologies found in flightless birds. We focused on a group of birds known as palaeognaths, which include the familiar ostrich, emu, cassowary, kiwi and rhea species, as well as a group of birds known as tinamous, which can fly and live in the tropics of the New World. The widespread distribution of these birds - found throughout the southern continents (Australia, New Zealand, Africa and South America) and other areas of the New World tropics - and their bizarre morphology, with their often large body size and sometimes just stubs of forelimb bones for wings, have puzzled biologists for centuries. We have employed modern genomics techniques to study how evolving protein coding genes and noncoding regulatory regions - the 'switches' that turn genes on and off - contribute to these dramatic morphologies. Over the centuries scientists have used many different kinds of organisms to understand how changes in the genome influence changes in the size, shape and behavior of organisms. It is widely acknowledged that such studies, even those in animals other than mammals, can provide important insight into human health and disease.

We started by sequencing the entirety of the genetic material - the genomes - of 11 species of flightless birds and tinamous, including a representative of an extinct group of palaeognathous birds called moas, which used to live in New Zealand bit were driven to extinction within a few hundred years of human colonization. This vast catalog of genomic information allowed us to build a genealogical tree relating these species to one another - a prerequisite for understanding what parts of the genome changed specifically in those lineages that lost flight. The genealogy (or phylogeny) indicated that fligt was in fact lost not just once in the common ancestor of the flightless species, but in fact multiple times. This so-called convergent evolution of flightlessness allowed us to use novel statistical appraoches to determine which parts of the genome changed repeatedly on branches of the phylogenetic tree leading to flightless species. In addition to detecting such regions, we also used modern genomics appraoches to determine which parts of the genome were  active and available to be copied into proteins while the fore- and hindlimbs of chickens were developing.  We were able to compare these regions in the chicken genome with those in the flightless birds to determine which parts of the genomes of flightless birds might have changed during evolution to cause reduction in the forelimb, rapid growth of the hindlimb, loss of the 'keel' on the sternum, where the flight muscles attach, or many of the other features that distinguish flightless birds from those that fly. Together these different sources of data allowed us to identify numerous regions of the genome, both coding and noncoding, that likely contributed to the skeletal modifications preciptating flightlessness. Surprisingly, the most important regions of the genome for loss of flight appear to be those noncoding regulatory regions that switch other genes on and off. These results corroborate those of other studies on other organisms implicating noncoding regions in morphological evolution.

In collaboration with co-PI Julia Clarke at the University of Texas at Austin, we helped develope novel computational pipelines for organizing data on the size and shape of organisms quickly and efficiently. Ultimately these morphological data will be combined with our extensive genomic data to better understand the interplay between genotype and phenotype in the evolution of flightless birds.

As part of this project we made numerous broader impacts. We trained postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and undergraduates in modern appraoches of biotechnology and bioinformatics. We conducted several workshops that helped disseminate modern techniques in bioinformatics and computational biology to diverse students in the US and around the world. In public lectures we showcased our results to audiences in the US and abroad. This project has helped promote modern genomics approaches in the study of evolutionary biology and may one day lead to insights into morphological abnormalities in humans.  Project such as this are important for understanding how the diversity of organisms on earth evolved and the various forces that cause biodiversity to change over time. We hope our results, which are freely available online, will facilitate a greater understanding between scientific fields as well as between science and the public.
